snippets.text: Many Proteobacteria synthesize acyl-homoserine lactone (AHL) molecules for use as signals in cell density-dependent gene regulation known as quorum sensing (QS) and response.
In most bacteria, a global level of regulation, termed quorum sensing (QS), exists involving intercellular communication via the production and response to cell density-dependent signal molecules.

In many pathogenic microorganisms, communication systems, collectively termed quorum sensing (QS), have been observed to control a number of bacterial behaviours including expression of virulence factors and the development of biofilms.

Bacteria can communicate within their own species (intra-species) but also between species (inter-species), for which they employ an autoinducer-2 quorum sensing system which is called the universal language of the bacteria.

Quorum sensing is a signaling mechanism through which bacteria modulate a number of cellular functions (genes), including sporulation, biofilm formation, bacteriocin production, virulence responses, as well as others.
Quorum sensing is a mechanism of cell-to-cell communication and is mediated by extracellular chemical signals generated by the bacteria when specific cell densities are reached.
Quorum sensing is used by a large variety of bacteria to regulate gene expression in a cell-density-dependent manner.

BACKGROUND
Quorum sensing or the bacterial information flow in an orchestrated manner is an essential feature of many pathogenic bacteria.
Quorum sensing is the means of communication between these bacteria to regulate a wide range of behavior patterns among them.
Quorum sensing is a process of cell-cell communication that allows bacteria to share information about cell density and adjust gene expression accordingly.
Quorum sensing is the phenomenon, whereby bacteria use signal molecules to communicate with each other.
The term 'quorum sensing' describes intercellular bacterial communication which regulates bacterial gene expression according to population cell density.
